Comment: No one would argue -- I certainly won't -- that the ACA is perfect. It's really a conservative compromise dating to the Nixon years, an alternative to truly universal healthcare. It can be improved; it should be improved. Obviously, neither Trump nor the Republicans have a plan to do that, or even the desire to do it.  "Repeal and replace" has always meant simply and only "repeal", as we are learning as we watch Trump flailing and floundering, attempting to save the parts of the ACA that people like and want, while having no coherent plan for doing that.  By all means, the ACA needs to be improved; but clearly Trump has no plan to do that.  My point was a very narrow one: that voting for Trump on pro-life grounds was at best naive; it was, for anyone who took the trouble to understand his illiteracy about healthcare policy, a cynical, hypocritical and dishonest rationalization for voting for a uniquely unqualified candidate.

Comment: Here are some reasons why I use YOC.  The total cost of a stock is the amount that I have at risk in that equity.  If the stock goes up or doubles, then the extra amount is invested elsewhere as are the dividends.  Hence I show the difference between the RIF's total book value and the market value because that profit is making more dividends on a constant basis by re-investment. The total cost of an equity is constant while the market value fluctuates constantly as the ticker goes by.

Comment: That is not the law.  And it has not been the law for the past 30 years.  Once a person is physically in Canada then they must have their refugee claim assessed as a matter of fundamental justice (our version of due process).  That was set out by the SCOC in Singh v Canada [1985] 1 S.C.R. 177;

"Per Dickson C.J. and Lamer and Wilson JJ.: 

Appellants, in the determination of their claims, are entitled to assert the protection of s. 7  of the Charter  which guarantees "everyone ... the right to life, liberty and security of the person and the right not to be deprived thereof except in accordance with the principles of fundamental justice". The term "everyone" in s. 7  includes every person physically present in Canada and by virtue of such presence amenable to Canadian law. "

If the refugee claimants are determined to be economic migrants and not Convention Refugees after their hearing then they will not be protected persons and subject to removal.

Comment: Hardly. Weather patterns vary with solar cycles. In addition to the 11 year cycle most people are familiar with, there are more extended cycles that result in "little ice ages" and major cooling and warming trends. Actual climatologists are trying to figure out what sort of cycle we are in, now. Our sun is acting very strangely - two South poles, a huge whole, a lack of sun spots, and swarms of solar storms. The fact is, they don't know if we're in a cooling or warming cycle. None of this, however, is due to human actions.

Human caused climate change is complete or mostly fiction. Climatologists, atmospheric scientists, and astronomers pretty much universally agree with that. Pollution is another story, however. Acid rain, from burning fossil fuels, desertification of landscape by removing vegetation and diverting water, etc. are quite real. You ignore those real problems, in favor of "green energy" corporate scams. Pay attention to the real problems we can do something about.

Comment: Hi Joe,
I would like to believe that they know not what they do, when they continually advocate for the profit driven health care system that has been the root of most personal bankruptcies in this country for the past 2-3 decades. 
As a one year cancer survivor myself (e.g. I can not yet be certain that I was cured by surgery), I can tell you that the prospect of losing one's entire life savings because of an illness, the prospect of leaving my wife not only a widow but saddled with medical debts, is about the worst stress you can add onto the fear of dying of cancer at a relatively young age. I am still financial sound only because of the ACA. I'd like to see everyone have that benefit, and I'd gladly pay for it in taxes.
The fundamental disagreement we have in this country in whether full access to health care, regardless of income level, should be a right. I believe it should be, and I always have. I think it's in the greater interest of this country as well as for each individual.

Comment: Unfortunately, if an organization needs to be decentralized, it means it is already somewhat centralized. Decentralization has to be done from the center that exists, except in the case of revolution.

There is no reason for a bishop to run a pontifical council, unless you want to centralize power. Have selected bishops gather to elect a new pope, rather than leave it in the hands of the Curia. Comment: As a funeral director and a Catholic, I (we) have always been told to explain to the Catholic family we are serving that although the church allows cremation, the cremains (ashes) must be buried or placed in a niche.  You can only imagine some of the comments WE get when explaining the church's preference (demand, would be more appropriate).  Just to give an example of how silly this is at times, we had gentleman that died last year and his family chose cremation.  Now--he was married twice, with both wives preceding him in death; his wishes were to have half of his ashes buried next to his first wife and the remaining half placed in the niche with his second wife; sounds easy, doesn't it? Well...not at the Catholic cemetery...can't split the ashes, church doesn't allow it.  I felt at least his family was following his wishes and they were not just casting their father's ashes aside.  Suffice it to say...I think some ashes ended up in the flowers of his first wife's grave...

Comment: The way I see it- as the atmosphere and the oceans warm the atmosphere becomes more and more saturated with water. Eventually something will happen (large volcanic eruption or a meteor strike perhaps) that will increase the planetary albedo causing cooling of the atmosphere and resulting in the extra moisture precipitating out. If the temperature and atmospheric moisture aberrations to the high side go too far, then perhaps we trigger an ice age ourselves when we eventually figure out how to deplete the CO2 etc once we've moved to renewables. Taking that sort of view though is difficult when you're worried about maximizing quarterly profits or paying a monthly hydro bill but it would be nice if people capable of projecting aims etc far into the future were not simply ridiculed because they point out that 1 + 1 = 2 over century and millennial scales- The science is pretty much like simple arithmetic when you get above the noise and chatter- sorry about that but get over it.

The Donnilles have every right to farm organically without the intrusion of herbicides or pesticides (predominantly herbicides) drifting onto their property and crops.  They have every right to lobby for a buffer zone on aerial spraying and such buffers will NOT destroy the timber industry.  In fact, the industry likely spends more money fighting such buffers than those buffers would cost in additional control of invasive plants by other means or in loss of timber production.

Comment: When BART was built in California, they had some difficulty it getting people to use it.  The issue was people having to travel so far by bus or car to get to a station. When they got off the train, the road a bike to their final work destination.

Comment: Sadly, it won't make a difference. Any money you might save will be eaten up by the other effects of the carbon tax - higher fuel costs, higher costs for food, goods, services - in short everything you buy. Where I live, there is no natural gas supply. Oil, propane, electric, and wood are our heating choices. There's no public transit. Outside of town, we have to use our own vehicles. Everything we buy is trucked in. Power rates are insane. Gasoline prices are rising. Grocery prices are rising. Businesses in town are hurting. Some have closed. In Wynne's rural Ontario, we're being eaten alive. And then I see her sitting next to Trudeau, smiling, while she dumps another tax on us.
Her cap-and-trade scam will turn into another Wynnedoggle, just like the GEA. Any benefits will go to her pals. The Law of Unintended Consequences will kick in. When it does, we'll all be exponentially worse off.

Comment: As in most debates, it's important to be specific and correct. What Mr. Whelan writes is just that. The weapon used in the Las Vegas mass shooting was a semi-automatic firearm to which a bump stock was added so as to obtain an increased rate of fire. Therefore Mr. Whelan is correct when he writes, "...it sounded like automatic fire." The firearm was semi-automatic.
This matters because some people, specifically those who know little about, and fear firearms, can easily be persuaded to join the gun control/confiscation camp with terms such as "automatic fire", "fully automatic rifle", "machine gun", "assault weapon", etc.
Technically, a fully automatic rifle continues to fire as long as the trigger is held back and there is ammunition in its clip. Bump stocks (and other add-on devices) require a bit of trigger finger dexterity so as to use the recoil-recovery-trigger reset-trigger press cycle to achieve an increased rate of fire with a SEMIAUTOMATIC firearm.

Comment: Many Asian women did indeed provide “comfort” services to the Japanese Imperial Forces during World War II, but I do not believe they did it at the point of a gun nor was it sexual slavery.    Throughout history, military forces have had no problem finding “comfort women” regardless of the country in which they operated and they were able to find them without kidnapping, coercion or threats of any kind.  Wars create horrible conditions which cause people to resort to often unthinkable means to survive.  For many women, it was the use of their bodies, and there usually was more supply than demand.  I personally witness this during the Korean War and during two years in Vietnam.  Some members of the Imperial Japanese forces no doubt forced women to have sex, which, of course, is rape, but I believe the “comfort women” who served the Imperial Japanese forces in brothels that sprung up and operated near Japanese bases did so voluntarily for pay.

Comment: It is interesting how deeply the "sea ice float on water so they don't affect sea level when it melts" myth has propagated.

Sea Water is a heavy salt solution, not pure water. Ice Bergs and Sea Ice are pure water. When they melt they take up more volume than the dense brine they displaced to float. That means that melted sea ice contributes to sea level rise.

Tim Ball has a parlor trick where he floats an ice cube in a glass of tap water at the beginning of an interview, marking the water level, then shows that the level hasn't risen at the end of the interview when the ice has melted. Ball never tries trick that with sea water.

Comment: See logic is grounded in metaphysics. There are many ways in which things can be considered better for many different beings. Better means something different for a basketball player (more excellent in his craft) than say a burger (more pleasing in taste). We have to clarify the being of what is talked about. In this case, if in our metaphysics we understand that vocation is an object, then Christ's statement of "better" would refer to objective excellence. However, this is not the case. Vocation is rather a project of existential possibility. It is a part of one's personal being-with-God. With this metaphysics, the logical statement takes on a different meaning because the terms are now referring to a different being. Thus, Christ's statement means Mary's vocation is the best expression of serving God for her. Her vocation is hers. It is part of her personal relationship with God. No one can take that from her and say "well she should be doing this instead."

Comment: For the most part, I agree with what you posted as a response. I'm all for keeping firearms out of the hands of persons who should not have them.

However, there is no way, short of a gun registry, which I oppose, to enforce the latter. Also, the databases with which our NICS and state police operate are woefully inadequate.
By what means would you enforce any law that require that guns not in actual use or being maintained, be locked up? Child access prevention laws might prevent some incidents but it's essentially reactive; enforced only after a mishap, unless there is a provision for periodic inspections of compliance. That might be a Fourth Amendment infraction.
I know enough about gun control progressives to know they'd gut the Second Amendment. Just look at some of the posts here. Example: You need to join a militia in order to keep and bear arms.

3. Pipeline releases are often reported first by nearby residents, not by companies' leak detection systems. Having alert, well-informed neighbours is step one in emergency preparedness: those who are most at risk are bound to be the most attentive & responsive to the abnormal.
4. NEB and companies need to establish databases of these vulnerable high-consequence sites in order to allow for closer monitoring re. public awareness, first responder awareness, site-specific emergency planning, integrity of the pipe in that area, etc.
5. NEB and companies should ensure that high-consequence/"sensitive use" facilities are no longer permitted to be built next to transmission pipelines. This will reduce the need for site-specific planning and monitoring later on.
6. Further to #5, companies need to be honest when they are circulated regarding proposed development next to their pipeline. Companies need to tell planners that pipeline releases present risks that are unacceptable.

  https://www.fin.gc.ca/drleg-apl/2017/bia-leb-0417-n-eng.asp#p1
ITA 
81(2)
Subsection 81(2) of the Act provides that allowances received by an elected member of a provincial legislature, for expenses related to the discharge of the member’s duties, are not required to be included in computing the member’s income to the extent that they do not exceed one-half the amount payable by way of salary, indemnity and other remuneration.

Comment: Peeing in the park/alley when you think no one is looking is not an offense that requires registration as a sex offender in the State of Colorado. It does not meet the elements of Indecent Exposure, which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person when done with the intent to arouse. It also does not meet the elements of Public Indecency (which only requires registration after a second conviction within 5 years), which requires a KNOWING exposure of genitals to the view of another person.

Also, the juvenile sex offender registry is not made available to the public in the same way as the adult sex offender registry. And first-time juvenile sex offenders are able to petition for de-registration once they have successfully completed their sentence.

Comment: Again, your initial disclaimer for your commentary is justified.

Note that I clearly stated that CO₂ is "the single most significant GHG in terms of INITIATING global temperature change". The water vapor mixing ratio only changes with temperature, and is a feedback to CO₂ changes. And again, the consensus estimate for the contribution to the GHE from water vapor is ~50% (not 91%), and the contribution from CO₂ is ~20%. 20% of 33K is not "3 C".

Water vapor is indeed the closest thing to a "black body" selective absorber, but it does so quite near the surface. The energy balance is determined by the energy flux differential at the effective emission height significantly higher in the troposphere where water vapor is scarce, and CO₂ remains well-mixed. In contrast to your odd assertion of "not much energy" at the absorption band of CO₂, a quick look at the Earth's Planck curve with GHG interaction tells a different story.

https://chriscolose.files.wordpress.com/2010/02/rad4.gif

Comment: My understanding is that after the clawbacks you got 2.5%/year increase. I am aware of the cap but can't really say I know how it affects most practising physicians. In NS we received 0%, 0%, 1% and 1.5% increases over the 4-year deal. We also have the second-lowest remuneration in Canada and the cost-of-living in Nova Scotia, while not Toronto or Vancouver, obviously, is not cheap...our taxes are exceeded only by Quebec although we enjoy a considerably inferior social safety net to that province...nevertheless, I don't complain. Economic times are not good, there is evidence inequality is growing within developed countries with worrisome consequences and physicians in Canada generally do well. I am not filthy rich by any means (nor do I have any desire to be) but I certainly don't have to worry where my next meal will come from. I would prefer in my province's case that any available public funds go to e.g. underpaid teachers and nurses. My opinion of course.

Comment: The inference here that there is "most likely well over R20-billion" belonging to these 4600 deregistered retirement funds, and therefore either awaiting payment to former members or already looted by unnamed parties, is not credible.  The process to deregister a fund requires certification that the fund has no remaining assets or liabilities.  The R20-billion claim would average to over R4-million per deregistered fund - presumably this would either be left in dormant accounts or would have been removed improperly, i.e. stolen.  But these were mainly small funds and their assets would typically have been no more than a few million Rands at best, in most cases - to suggest that R4 or 5 million per fund would simply have been "left over", unclaimed, once the in-service members and any pensioners had been transferred out, is simply not plausible.  I have no doubt that further investigation, if the courts deem this necessary, will confirm this.

Comment: Historic Detail — The 6% "PERS pickup" happened in 1979.  Many state employee bargaining contracts had a Cost-of-Living index on them.  But in 1979, the inflation rate was 18%.  To save the state money, the employees agreed to having the public employer "pick up" the 6% contribution (to match the previous 6% employer share) and thereby SAVE the state 12% of a Cost of Living adjustment.  Now of course, critics say employees "aren't even paying for their own retirement."  What was a GIFT to the State of Oregon, taking 6% instead of the contracted 18% that year, is now seen as "cheating."  
   It really comes down to having a retirement plan still in place when most big businesses have been able to "get rid" of those things for their workers so as to get more money for the "Golden Parachutes" for top management.
    I know one employee of a large local firm who was fired the week before he was to retire, after 45 years with the company.  Should THAT be "reformed"?

Comment: Have gone through some books and papers looking for the Hawaiian pre-contact population estimate of one million people.  Believe it was Stannard who first said this, but it might have been Kirch. Thomas Dye and Toni Todd thanks for your thoughts.  (You guys know Dye?)

To begin to understand how 800,00-1,000,000 people could have lived here in the olden days, begin looking at the dry land field systems.  Most have disappeared under sugar and pineapple fields, but many still survive as archeological ruins in pastures around Waimea, Big Island, and as the inland Kona Field System.

And the bulk of human nutrition in the old days came from marine sources.  Limu, shellfish, crustaceans, shoreline and canoe fish.  A managed fishery. But the key part of that habitat, the wetlands, are gone.  No nursery=no seafood.

Can we replicate this?  Probably not.  But you're missing some wonderful food if you ignore small and part-time farmers or your friend with the boat isn't sharing his catch!

Comment: Of the story told here, the Alaska individuals small businesses who can hire directly, are most likely to be up-front, honest, and actually provide a reasonably good experience for the J-1 worker. 

To say there were no qualified workers for these seasonal positions has always been part of the build-up to this situation in Alaska. I've seen it personally, where I was hired to work for a Unalaska-DutchHarbor shoreside fish processor. 

In the Anchorage office, they had all my local information. At the point of hire, (Alaska) my wages were supposed to be $5.50 p/hr including room, board, & transportation. Once I arrived at the company's Dutch Harbor office, the wage
was $2.50 per hour, had to pay $11 per day for shared room in old ship anchored in harbor, & was expected to stay extended season or pay restitution full-fare both ways. Airfare: $5,000. in 1977.

Other recent examples, 'displaced local' jobs due to prioritized Seattle Hire +wage; Princess & other tour/fish/hotel co. did it.

Comment: The Tackling Violent Crime Act raises the legal age of sexual consent in Canada to 16 from 14, the first time it has been raised since 1892.  But the law includes a "close-in-age exception," meaning 14- and 15-year-olds can have sex with someone who is less than five years older.

However, the age of consent is 18 years where the sexual activity "exploits" the young person when it involves prostitution, pornography or occurs in a relationship of authority, trust or dependency (e.g., with a teacher, coach or babysitter). Sexual activity can also be considered exploitative based on the nature and circumstances of the relationship, e.g., the young person’s age, the age difference between the young person and their partner, how the relationship developed (quickly, secretly, or over the Internet) and how the partner may have controlled or influenced the young person.

Comment: In my understanding, the only violation of free speech would come from a requirement to use another individuals preferred pronoun. While it is perfectly reasonable to politely ask one to use your preferred pronoun, and perfectly reasonable and respectful for one to comply, it is absolutely within ones right to decline to use said pronoun. Similarly, one in possession of a doctorate degree may reasonably request to be called Dr. X, and it's perfectly reasonable and respectful for the other to comply, but they can decline to refer to you as a doctor if they so choose without reprisal. That's free speech.

Now, Russia attempting to influence the presidency and potential coverups do equate to criminal action, and I don't think they hurt us all if they help lead to a clear understanding of exactly where people's priorities lie. It's not fabricated, there was indeed an attempt to influence the election. None of the leaks assume Trump colluded with the Russians but there is a lot of suspicious behavior and the placing it in the public narrative is a necessary struggle. I don't have a conclusion based on the leaks - but I think a lot of them deserve answers. Trump saying Comey was a "nut job" isn't worthy of a leak. But knowingly hiring Flynn when he was under active investigation, Trump's attempt to block the investigation, and then Trump's public vs. private reasons for firing Comey are all important things and not just partisan bickering.

Comment: By Rep. Lora Reinbold, from the Juneau Empire, April 22, 2016

“A useful benchmark is to compare our current spending to previous budgets during frugal times when government operations were being delivered at a lower price. The FY06 operating budget provides a solid benchmark, as it predates the rapid rise in the price of oil, and revenue, that fueled bigger spending. In FY06, agency operations, including supplemental spending, were $5.24 billion (FY06). Using FY06 as a benchmark, and adjusting for inflation at 26 percent (data source: 2006-16 Consumer Price Index, Municipality of Anchorage) and then adjusting for a population increase from 675,000 to 738,000 (data source: Alaska Department of Labor and Workforce Development) over the past 10-year period would suggest equivalent government services could be delivered for $7.2 billion. That’s $1 billion, or 12 percent, lower than our current FY17 budget proposals in Juneau.”

Comment: I was in exactly the same position many years ago, running a smaller satellite company in Canada when our parent company in the USA was bought by a European conglomerate.  After stating that I would not move to Pittsburgh, I was told "If you stay for three months and wind down the Canadian operation you will get a good severance."  I had worked for the company for over 10 years.  As the closeout date approached, and I had nothing in writing, I started to push for the severance package and was told "You were offered a job in Pittsburgh", albeit a demotion since I was moving from the position of General Manager back to a project engineer, "so, if you don't take the job you get nothing but your two weeks vacation!"  Seemed like a good case of constructive dismissal to me, but was told I had to show damages, like being out of work for months.  Your best protection is to be a marketable commodity in the job market.

Comment: Not to be too anal, but you mean VPSO (Village Public Safety Officer), not VSPO. And I believe Wassillie, the victim, was a VPO (Village Police Officer), not a VPSO. There is a big difference. A VPSO goes through state training & is recognized & supervised & paid by the state. There are way more VPOs than VPSOs. VPOs get a lot less training, & none of it is from the state that I know of. VPOs get lower pay, & VPOs are not officially recognized by the state due to the state's  opposition to tribal sovereignty. VPOs are paid & supervised by tribal councils. VPOs have high turnover & are often very young guys. VPSOs are meant to be a career option & have longer term professionals, generally. Both jobs are very tough & involve putting yourself in danger without a gun. High stress & low pay. Lots of alcohol-fueled domestic disputes, sometimes relatives. 

And to #3, yes the booze came from Bethel, the only hub here. The villages all vote to be dry but BET lets it pour in & profits from it.

Comment: Well, before changing tax policy, let's look at the upside for REITs, here and elsewhere.  One:  they are well-designed as a means of attracting investment capital, money used to great productive purpose.  Two:  The projects thus attracted generate enormous property taxes, GET and TAT income for the state and counties.  Three:  They create jobs, thousands of them, with all the benefits that flow from employment, to include income taxes paid to Hawaii.  Do we want to put Hawaii at a competitive disadvantage with the other 49 states by imposing a tax those other states recognize as counter-productive?  Does Hawaii need another economic headwind?

 Hawaiian residents are investors, too.  Income derived from out-of-state REITs in which Hawaiian residents invest are taxed here at home but not elsewhere.  That isn't "unfair," nor is the tax treatment unfair.  Sometimes foregoing a tax is a bigger contribution to the public good than is imposing yet another tax burden.

Comment: Yeah, I'e been living with this issue for most of my life. I'm happy to keep it alive.

There's no question that men who make sexual overtures from a position of power commit an abuse of power. And yes, it's exactly these blurry lines that become problematic.

When I was quite young (I may even have been a minor) I had a boss who got sexual with me when we were alone in a room. I rebuffed him, and he was a gentleman about it. I was really annoyed, but I continued to work at that job for a while. Was it an abuse of power? Yes. Was it a crime? Actually, legally it may have been. But I don't think of it as a crime. Women used to experience this kind of stuff all the time. I'd like to think the culture has changed a bit since then.

Unfortunately, as you may remember, I have also been a rape victim. So I give women who claim they've been raped the benefit of the doubt. But...at times, it's not the truth.

Comment: It was originally set up as an illness insurance system, as you say, to prevent people from losing their homes due to serious illness. Since illness strikes at a fairly consistent rate of 1% per day, it was easy to predict and costs easy to contain. And it worked! Slowly however, it changed from an illness system to a health care (preventive) system, which theoretically sounds great, but now, instead of covering 1% of the population at any one time, it covers 100% and costs are impossible to predict. Like many things that are good in theory, the health care system is far more difficult to put into practice, and very rapidly we have run into the situation where the majority of funds are spent on the "worried well", and once again the seriously-ill are being plunged into debt to receive needed treatment. 
You don't notice this, of course, until you become one of the 1%.

Comment: Loans from the bank of Mom-and-Dad are basically daisy-chaining risk in real estate, especially since the down payments often come from the parents' HELOC. If this one market corrects, it's not just that junior's place is underwater, Mom and Dad won't get repaid AND their own real estate nest egg goes down in value.

Many people seem to not realize that behaviors like this contribute to unaffordability, in the same way that facilitating more borrowing or creating new buyer incentives also drive prices up. All these things help someone get into the market today and bid up prices further in the future. (I am absolutely not discounting the impact of foreign money, of course.)

If we allowed government interference in other markets the same way we manipulate (and fixate) on real estate, we would be branded communists. Mom and Dad are just making it worse. And that over-priced condo they're stretching for today won't cut it long-term and won't help junior move into a bigger place later.

Comment: It is worth emphasizing two changes rushed through yesterday by the Trump Administration.

One change removes restrictions on coal mining companies, freeing them up to pollute streams and forests with the waste from coal mining.

The other change keeps it private when American oil companies offer huge, bribe-like sums of money to overseas officials to get access to oil fields, removing a previous rule that required such payments to be publicized.

It is unclear how any Trump supporters would "sell" those policy changes to regular, everyday voters. Indeed, both rules are going to benefit the top one percent (suit-wearing executives at the coal and oil companies), not the little voter guy whose family fishes or drinks water from the streams, or who wants more clean, home-grown energy independence for America.

Comment: Still not secure - email I got from Foscam - dated June 12 2017
The vulnerabilities affect "Foscam" branded cameras and cameras manufactured by China-based Shenzhen Foscam only. The vulnerabilities DO NOT affect Amcrest or FDT branded cameras which are produced by a separate factory and R&D team led by US-based Amcrest (formerly Foscam US and now Amcrest), which is totally unrelated to China-based Shenzhen Foscam. 

Amcrest split off from China-based Shenzhen Foscam in 2015 / 2016 due to issues relating to distribution, lack of security and quality control and thus Amcrest and FDT cameras are totally unaffected by these latest security vulnerabilities.

Comment: Interesting information.  I think there's a difference between "strong"--which I think the Duck players were (shoot, a 160 lb distance runner can be "strong"), and "powerful," which obviously OL and DL guys need to be.  In the 80s I tutored a few Duck footballers, including a 215 lb linebacker who said he was "rejected" (as in just bounced off) by a Nebraska lineman after a beat down in Lincoln.  
The whole Duck style under since Belotti was the fast offense, needing quick O-linemen.  So practice was quick-on-quick.  Ngata and a few others were strong, but it was quick that scored the points, not push.  So beating Auburn and Ohio State--and even Stanford--in the trenches was a no-go.  Maybe that'll change now.  I know the players loved Coach Rad, and wish him well, but clearly Coach Taggart wants to do it his way.  It means, by the 2019 seasons, no excuses.
I'm going with optimistic, for now.

Comment: So what is the global economic effect of permanently losing half of all global customers?  Somewhere around -50% GDP growth?  

My own view of sustainability now just one class away from a Master's degree in the subject at CU-Denver, after a 31-year career in wholesale food supply chain, warehousing, and distribution is that all that sustainability will do is prolong the inevitable perhaps as-long as a generation or two. 

My worry centers around large refugee flows out of places that can no-longer support large urban populations year-round after their aquifers are exhausted and their surface water supply becomes unsustainable.  Mexico City is a good example, Juarez is another.

The population of Mexico City is 4 times that of the State of Colorado and a recent peer-reviewed study of their water supply forecast 10-12 million refugees as soon as 2030.  What city or State to the north of Mexico City has enough water to spare to take in 20% of that number?   Just one:  Denver.

Comment: The average investor with less than a million or even two million invested doesn't need to worry about diversification (owning 20-30 stocks).

Just buy a several solid blue chip stocks from different sectors, 6 to 10 stocks for the first million or two works just fine.

Even at 3 or 4 million I wouldn't concern myself with diversification. Its really only those managing large pools of money (tens or hundreds of millions) that must suffer the need to diversify, spread risk over dozens of holdings.

The same can be said for foreign exposure, the average investor doesn't require foreign exposure. There are enough solid Canadian listed companies that you don't need foreign markets in your portfolio.

Comment: "They are offering billions of dollars more than the Conservative government had put on the table."
============

Actually no they aren't.

The Conservatives were offering increases tied to nominal GDP with a minimum of 3%.  The Liberals are offering a straight 3.5%.  Since nominal GDP was expected to grow at about 4% per year on average the Conservatives deal would probably have resulted in larger increases on average, though the Liberal deal had more consistent and certain increases.

The only place where the Liberals were offering more was the new home and mental health care, though even there we're only talking about roughly $1.0B/year.

On the whole the total dollar value is a wash between the Liberal and Conservative plans, just calculated slightly differently.

Comment: My husband and I live in the Ebey's Landing National Historical Reserve. Yes, aircraft fly all directions over our house, including jets, helicopters, and reconnaissance planes. However, you might see and hear 3 jets in the morning or early afternoon, and 3 in the late afternoon or evening.

For the most part, by the time you hear the jets, they're already out of sight. However, it's doubtful the noise of the jet lasts more than 60 seconds. That means if 6 jets happen to pass over our house, and conversely EBay's Reserve, it comprises 6 minutes out of the 1,440 minutes in a day or around .42% of a 24-hour period.

Chances are, if a visitor saw a Navy jet pass overhead, they'd be thrilled. They're exciting to see, especially if they're wing-in-wing. If there's a health issue, it would be minuscule.

There at dozens of noises that last significantly longer and are more damaging, such as a jack-hammer, revved up car or truck speeding down Highway 20, hum of an ultra-light, etc.

Comment: This is nothing like the sub-prime mortgage crisis in the US.  There are three biggest differences between Canada and the US .
The first is that making and insuring sub-prime mortgages was never a performance measure for CMHC as it was with Fanny Mae and Freddy Mac.  CMHC must still do its required underwriting and due diligence and it has the power to reject mortgage insurance.  
The second is that should a lending institution be found to have NOT undertaken its due diligence, then the CMHC mortgage insurance is void meaning that the lending institution must absorb the loss of any defaults.
The third is that Ontario and most other provinces do not allow for non-recourse mortgages, i.e. even if people walk away from their homes they are still responsible for any outstanding debt.
So you can see that Canada is nothing like the US.

Comment: The $30-35 million cost of this road equates to probably about $130,000 per resident of the community and good on them when the road is finally completed.  However, why has there been no cost benefit analysis done on a bridge to Shoal Lake 39 (the channel separating the 2 communities is about 400 meters wide) which would likely come in much cheaper and eliminate the extra 30-40 kilometres added by the new road on a one way trip to Kenora.  Secondly, once the road is completed, how will one ensure that residents do not travel on an ice road to cross the channel anyways, and shorten the extra travel distance? Lastly, once the road is completed, will the government of Ontario proceed with the twinning of Hwy 17 between Kenora and the Ontario-Manitoba border, a project which was promised 7 years ago? This stretch of highway, like much of Hwy 17 in Northern Ontario is a death trap, particularly in winter and summer week-ends.

Comment: Okay, my second major problem with this article. I am not an historian, so I can't be sure, but I'm pretty sure that the "sex for resources" exchange type of marriage never existed. Up until the early 20th century, I am fairly sure that marriage was fundamentally about securing, maintaining, and extending family wealth. Both men and women were jointly providing services, and both were getting sex, but most negotiations were familial anyway. And even later, once married women were hardly the "keepers" of sex - they were subject to the will of their husbands, leading to John Stuart Mill quote on marriage as the invisible tyranny. So anyway, a far cry from this presentation of "good old days" marriage as a negotiation between two people, marriage was a familial economic planning activity involving the subjugation of women.  But women still bought in because it was the only way they could have sex without suffering community censure.

Hard work DID allow many to progress, but racism, sexism, and various prejudices have held back many who otherwise should have done better if hard work was the only factor. The income disparity that allows a few to prosper at the expense of the many, is a cancer that eats into any societal good will and willingness to work for the common good. Comment: Cont.

Africa. By far, the largest regional percentage increase in population by 2050 will be in Africa, whose population can be expected to at least double from 1.1 billion to about 2.3 billion. That projection, however, depends on the assumption that sub-Saharan Africa's total fertility rate (TFR, the average number of children per woman) will decline from 5.1 to approximately 3.0 by 2050. That decline, in turn, assumes that the use of family planning in the region will rise significantly. But recent surveys from many sub-Saharan African countries have indicated that TFR decline is either slower than projected or is not taking place at all. Only 20 percent of married women in sub-Saharan Africa use a modern form of family planning, the lowest rate in the world.
PRB population Reference Bureau

Comment: Contrary to what people learn from TV and Hollywood, police do not shoot to kill;  They shoot only to stop a lethal threat, and to stop it immediately before such threat can be carried out.  The down-side?  Immediately stopping a lethal threat from a human being requires serious damage to those parts of the body that support life.  Furthermore, to ensure that requisite immediate stoppage of the lethal threat, seriously-damaging hits must be certain, and the largest and easiest part of a human to hit with bullets under the stress and pressure of a lethal threat is central body mass.
     Shooting someone in a limb does NOT constitute less-than-lethal force;  Any bullet, anywhere on a human body, can cause death--and one that does not strike an immediately-disabling area doesn't stop a lethal threat, either.
     Please also note that the Troopers worked mightily to save this man's life once he was no longer a threat;  That certainly does not indicate that they 'shot to kill,' does it?

Comment: Hi DIII. 

Sorry for the late response here, but just wanted to explain how the commenting platform works. Civil Comments is a crowd-sourced moderation system. If a comment is deleted, it is not because a moderator at Seattle Weekly disagrees with it, but because the community of commenters has decided that it is not civil or valuable. It is not a perfect system, which is why we still have moderators checking in to make sure that the comments that are deleted are deleted for the right reasons (hate speech, threats, blatant misinformation), and not purely for ideological reasons. We often approve comments that the community disapproves, but rarely do we disapprove comments that the community approves. 

Here is a video that explains how the platform works.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MjdjPbazpp8

Thanks for reading, and I hope you will continue to comment. 

Mark Baumgarten
Editor in Chief

Comment: People may be wondering about the international legal principles that Israel is violating with its actions in the West Bank. There are two primary ones, the first having to do with Israel's commitments under the UN Charter, and the second Israel's commitments under the Geneva Conventions.

To the first, no nation may capture territory in war and claim it as its own. (Nations may only temporarily occupy territory outside their borders. Then they must withdraw.)

To the second, no nation may move its own citizens to reside on territory that is temporarily occupied through war. Doing so is a form of ethnic cleansing, which is both a war crime and a crime against humanity.

These are not trivial violations, in other words. The first is a cornerstone of International order, while the second is a cornerstone of humanitarian concern.

Comment: I know this is a very old article, but Simons was not Alaska's first licensed guide. He was the very first licensed Master Guide with license 001. However, the very first overall licensed guide was Andrew Berg who received his license in 1908, the same year Simons arrived in Alaska. As the guide program developed and became more formalized they developed a second class of game warden/licensed guide and created the Master Guide category which is how Simons is credited as being number 1. In effect both men were the first licensed guides but that was because there became two categories of guides at different times.

Comment: Ugotta B Kidding, 

I feel bad for you that you get so much satisfaction out of being such a constant source of negativity online. Why does that make you feel good? I don't know you or know how you've chosen to live your life, but as someone who has truly dedicated themselves to something they love, I can say that all of my decisions are based upon intensive forethought and a careful examination of potential outcomes. Comment: Yes, we have a representative democracy. Our elected officials are supposed to represent our best interests. Their actions were to be restrained by the other two branches of government. When established, much of this nation was illiterate and ignorant about the issues, especially at the federal level. (Some days I wonder if much has changed🙁)  Most elected officials weren't worried about a career in politics; the model was that they served their country, then returned home to their day jobs. But those were simpler times. 
Consider the length of our Constitution, our primary governing document. Even with amendments it is dwarfed by most legislation. The ACA, which covers a mere 1/6th of our economy, is over 2,000 pages long! Who has time to read & analyze the issues it presents. No wonder it's such a mess. 

So I'll continue to vote for candidates who seem to represent my best interests. I'm not interested in the tyranny of a democratic majority, with lock step representatives.

Comment: Nice info, but the recreational grows will be different. A canopy of 1/4 acre with no plant number restrictions means that they can grow perhaps one plant per square foot, each in 5-gallon fabric pots or sown from seed in soil, and harvested small in a few months. The water usage for small potted plants is minimal, about 500 gallons per year for four plants. I use a $40 hose water filter that removes most of the chlorine. Now if you take it up a big notch and farm high thc autoflowering cannabis like Canadian Finola oilseed autoflowering hemp, you can use mechanized outdoor crop farming techniques and sow 10 seeds per square foot. Then you get 100,000 plants per 1/4 acre. Even at one plant per square foot, the recreational farms would have 10,000 plants. Even if they only yield on ounce trimmed bud per plant, that's 625 pounds worth $10 million wholesale from one farm per 10,000 small, quick plants, not to mention all the extracts that can be gotten from the remainder of the plants.

Comment: In neither answer was the matter of how the individual obtained information on someone else's pay addressed.   This is significant as there may be a privacy violation. It is certainly appropriate for an employee to inquire about his or her pay, but it is absolutely inappropriate to reference the pay of a specific individual unless this information is in the public domain.    Further, length of experience is only one consideration in determining salary.  What about education and performance?  Two people can do the same job and one just happens to perform better.  With respect to market research around pay, companies typically do this and measure themselves against an appropriate peer group of comparable organizations.  Often this is conducted through a third party.  Certainly, an individual can do some checking but the data is only as reliable as the source.  
G & M, it would probably be a good idea to vet information provided in the answers in this column sometimes.

Comment: Was on the front line (literally, as cashier) for close to five years as retirement approached.  Suited me for a lot of reasons--Including the fact that it was "only" part-time.  That worked: there were very few full-time cashiers left at my food-chain store by the time I signed up in 2009. Part-timers got hours cut back (although nobody worked a 2-hr. shift, but lots of 4-hrs stints. Me, too.) 

The job--and the people doing it--taught me a lot. One discovery: many part-time 4-hr shift workers earning less than $18 an hour DROVE to work and back whenever they had a shift.  Insane. I walked no-cost 15 min. each way from my back door.  One of the other reasons I worked there.  See?  Just like Loblaws, ya gotta cut overhead...

Animal companion foster organizations (led by pioneering Anchorage organizations such as Friends of Pets and Alaska SPCA the past several decades) demonstrate the power of community action every day and hour.  They've created incredible models for responsible rescue, fostering, care and the adoption of dogs and cats to forever families.   They are integrated into the community through wide-reaching volunteer networks.  They also advocate for responsible pet stewardship.
Next step:  create, strengthen and enforce regulations to ensure non-profits and businesses in Anchorage's animal care industry are operating in clean, healthy environments for those they care for.

Comment: I agree that fossil fuels served us with great distinction and helped us achieve our current level of technological and social sophistication. Comment: Almost 30 years after the oil tanker Exxon Valdez hit Bligh Reef and smeared Prince William Sound with more than 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil, a team of state and federal scientists have concluded the spill – as bad as it looked and as much impact as it had on marine mammals and birds – appears to have done no real damage to fisheries.

“We found no evidence supporting a negative EVOS  (Exxon Valdez Oil Spill) impact on herring, sockeye salmon, or pink salmon productivity, and weak evidence of a slightly positive EVOS signal on Copper River Chinook (king) salmon productivity,” the study says. “It is unclear how EVOS may have impacted Chinook salmon positively.”

Comment: Find a lonely place on public land near an earthen drainage ditch (they are full of run-off fertilizer from local lawns) move down the slope of the ditch about half way and dig down till you see obvious moister. Place your fully started seedling(s) in the hole(s) and cover the roots with good potting soil lightly packed, early to mid April (depending on temp).
Go away for two weeks, then return to observe (walk the dog) and add, or not, some properly mixed liquid fertilizer designed for tomato plants around the stalk. Hopefully on a rainy day.
Leave them alone. Once every two weeks or so check on them but not obviously, fertilize as you like. When I went to pick mine up in early Oct. I couldn't find them, I could smell them but I couldn't see them. As I looked around I was suddenly shocked and afraid to see 8-9ft plants thriving and fully ready for harvest. Comment: An interesting piece and some interesting observations in some of the comments.  Its important to differentiate between FinTrac and the OSFI.  The latter was formulated in the 1980s following the collapse of  the Western Bank and observations by the Estey Commission that the regulators were too close to the banks. OSFI has done a great job  since its creation, winning praise post 2008.  Fintrac was largely a product of new laws post 9/11 to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. Before then, Canada was a haven for money laundering; RBC was famous for letting itself be used by Haiti's Papa and Baby Doc for money laundering.  It seems that, while progress has been made, the culture of strict anti-money laundering compliance continues to elude us. We rightly deserve our reputation for weak anti money laundering compliance - which, by the way, may help to explain  certain real estate bubbles in Toronto and Vancouver

Comment: "The state doesn’t want yet another Cleary lawsuit, although it would be easy to bring, especially if it knowingly creates conditions that violate Cleary provisions."

The fact that the court order that's supposedly being violated is no longer in effect seems relevant to a piece about how locking more people up would violated the court order.

More importantly, it would not at all be easy to bring a similar lawsuit in the future: the legislature prohibited such lawsuits in state court in 1999 with the passage of the Alaska Prison Litigation Reform Act. These claims are likewise not allowed under the federal Prison Litigation Reform Act. So as long as we have an attorney general willing to vigorously assert the state's sovereign interests against frivolous lawsuits, we shouldn't have anything to worry about.

Comment: Part 1
Partially agree, MJ. 

At issue is your rejection of the PARTICIPATION OF THE FAITHFUL at mass as "worshiping," insisting instead on the term "assisting."  

I absolutely agree with you, possibly contrary to your meaning, that we all  "offer sacrifice." 

Sacrifice is essentially the primordial human action of "gift giving" when the gift is given to God (or a god). 

More specifically, our Eurcharistic Liturgy duplicates that form of Jewish sacrifice called a "communion sacrifice" (NJB translation), in which (1) worshipers bring a food-animal gift to the altar (2) for the priest to offer to God by killing and burning the animal (giving it to God by removing it from our use), and (3) God in turn invites the worshiper to share the gift as a roast at a communal meal.

(This is structurally the same guest bringing a bottle of wine or box of after-dinner-mints as a dinner gift, and the host serving that wine with the meal or sharing the mints after the meal.)

Comment: While I agree that it is NOT the government's job to ensure any given corporation, or even corporations in general, make money, it is a fair argument that corporations SHOULD make money.  That is the whole reason why they exist and if they aren't making money then they will close up shop, putting people out of work and hurting pension plans and personal savings, not to mention government revenues.

Corporations SHOULD make money and there is absolutely nothing wrong with them making more money (and, likewise, there is absolutely nothing wrong with you choosing not to purchase the goods or services they offer if you feel they are charging too much).  Government's job is simply to ensure that these corporations have an equal and level playing field so that competition can exist, and THAT is where Ms. Layton's comments fall flat on their face.  She is arguing against free markets and competition, which is precisely what drives innovation in the first place.

The ASD has indeed a budgeting problem.  It now has as many students 48.000 as it did in 1998, the formula funds ASD as of it has 77.000 students.

Nothing about the continuing rise of automation, nothing about the rise of a new consumer market in China and other parts of the world that is buying more and more of the stuff we are good at making, no mention of the rising expectations of Chinese - and others - for the same freedoms and advantages we take for granted. It has not been a zero sum game for many years, but now that the US is again moving closer to the Chinese democratic model with the full weight of the media and and other founts of social opinion such as houses of worship behind the campaign, it may well again become just that - and that would be to the detriment to all of us outside the 1%. It will be interesting to see if the hegemony of competing empires reasserts itself, or if the trend falters on the disappointments and doubts of of its so-far bedazzled acolytes.. Interesting and entertaining perhaps. But we have to wait now to see..
